title: 105_hr2978
content:
SHORT TITLE; FINDINGS. The "65th Infantry Regiment Commemorative Coin Act" recognizes the brave soldiers from Puerto Rico who served in the 65th Infantry Regiment during the Korean conflict. They are honored for their sacrifices and heroism, with many receiving prestigious awards for their service. The 65th Infantry Regiment played a crucial role in rescuing the 1st Division of the US Marine Corps in Hagaru-ri during the Korean conflict. They provided a safe corridor for the Marines to escape and formed a protective rear guard during the retreat to Hungnam. The regiment was the last to leave the beachhead in the Christmas eve evacuation of Hungnam in 1950. The 65th Infantry Regiment saved the 3d Infantry Division from a surprise attack by over 1,000 North Korean soldiers. They were praised for their heroism in battle, receiving accolades including a letter from General Douglas MacArthur. The 65th Infantry Regiment in Korea demonstrated valor and loyalty to the United States, earning praise for their achievements in battle. General Douglas MacArthur commended their resolute will to victory and devotion to shared standards of human relations. In honor of Puerto Ricans in the 65th Infantry Regiment who fought in the Korean conflict, the Secretary of the Treasury will mint $1 silver coins weighing 26.73 grams, with a diameter of 1.500 inches, containing 90% silver and 10% copper. These coins will be legal tender and considered numismatic items. The Secretary will obtain silver for minting coins from stockpiles established under the Strategic and Critical Materials Stock Piling Act. The design of the coins will be determined as per the Act. The design of the coins minted under this Act shall symbolize the courage and valor of Puerto Ricans in the 65th Infantry Regiment during the Korean conflict. Each coin will feature a value designation, the year "1999", and inscriptions of "Liberty", "In God We Trust", "United States of America", and "E Pluribus Unum". The design will be chosen by the Secretary in consultation with relevant parties. The design of the coins minted under this Act will symbolize the courage and valor of Puerto Ricans in the 65th Infantry Regiment during the Korean conflict. The design will be chosen by the Secretary in consultation with relevant parties and reviewed by the Citizens Commemorative Coin Advisory Committee. SEC. 5. ISSUANCE OF COINS.

Coins minted under this Act shall be issued in uncirculated and proof qualities at a designated Mint facility starting January 1, 1999, with minting authority ending on December 31, 1999.

SEC. 6. SALE OF COINS. The coins issued under this Act will be sold by the Secretary at a price equal to the face value, a surcharge, and the cost of designing and issuing the coins. Bulk sales will be offered at a discount, and prepaid orders will be accepted with a reasonable discount. All sales will include a $10 surcharge per coin. SEC. 7. GENERAL WAIVER OF PROCUREMENT REGULATIONS. No procurement laws apply to goods and services needed for this Act, except for equal employment opportunity laws. All surcharges from the sale of coins under this Act go to the Korean War Veterans Memorial Fund for the American Battle Monuments Commission to use. The Commission can use the funds for costs related to the Korean War Veterans Memorial and for a ceremony for the 65th regiment after consulting with specific associations. The Puerto Rican Veterans Association of Massachusetts and the Puerto Rican-American Research Institute conducted a ceremony at the Korean War Veterans Memorial to honor the Puerto Ricans of the 65th Infantry Regiment for their service during the Korean conflict. The Comptroller General of the United States has the right to audit the American Battle Monuments Commission's expenditures related to the funds paid under this Act. SEC. 9. FINANCIAL ASSURANCES. The Secretary must ensure minting coins won't cost the government. Payment for coins requires full payment, security, or a guarantee from a depository institution.
